title: How It Works | Splits Network
description: A clear walkthrough of the split-fee recruiting process — from role posting to automated fee distribution. Understand the model before you engage.
author: Splits Network

blocks.subtitle: The split-fee model has connected recruiters for decades. Splits Network gives it the infrastructure to work at scale — transparent, tracked, and paid automatically.
blocks.imageAlt: Network diagram illustrating the connection between companies, recruiters, and candidates

blocks.heading: What Split-Fee Recruiting Actually Means
paragraphs: In traditional recruiting, a single agency owns the relationship with both the company and the candidate. They collect the full placement fee. Split-fee recruiting changes that dynamic: the hiring company posts a role, any qualified recruiter can engage, and when a placement is made, the fee is divided between the job-posting party and the placing recruiter.

The result is broader candidate coverage for companies, access to more roles for recruiters, and a marketplace where specialization is rewarded. Everyone earns based on their contribution. Splits Network is the platform that makes this model operationally viable — handling agreements, pipelines, and payments in one place.

blocks.heading: From Role Posted to Placement Paid
blocks.subtitle: Five clear steps. Every stage is tracked on the platform so all parties have full visibility.

steps.title: Company Posts a Role
steps.description: A hiring company creates a role listing with job requirements, compensation range, and fee structure. They set the total placement fee and the split percentage — for example, 20% of first-year salary, split 50/50. Terms are public before any recruiter engages.

steps.title: Recruiters Discover and Engage
steps.description: Specialized recruiters browse the marketplace and engage with roles matching their expertise and candidate network. Each engagement is a formal agreement — the recruiter sees and accepts the fee terms before beginning work.

steps.title: Candidates Are Matched and Submitted
steps.description: Engaged recruiters submit candidates through the platform. AI matching scores each submission against the role requirements. Hiring managers review candidates in their shared ATS pipeline, advance them through stages, and coordinate interviews.

steps.title: Placement Is Made
steps.description: When the hiring company makes an offer and the candidate accepts, the placement is confirmed on the platform. The system logs the start date, verifies the hire, and begins the guarantee period clock.

steps.title: Fees Split Automatically
steps.description: After the guarantee period passes, the placement fee is calculated against the confirmed compensation. The company is invoiced via Stripe. The placing recruiter's share is paid out automatically. Every amount is visible to all parties.

blocks.heading: One Posting, Many Recruiters
paragraphs: When a role goes live on Splits Network, it reaches every recruiter in the network simultaneously. Specialists engage based on their expertise — not based on who has an existing agency relationship with you.

items.question: What happens if a candidate declines after an offer is made?
items.answer: The placement is not confirmed until the candidate starts. If an offer is declined, the role remains active and engaged recruiters can continue submitting. No fee is triggered.

items.question: How long is the standard guarantee period?
items.answer: The guarantee period is set by the hiring company when they post the role — typically 30, 60, or 90 days. If the candidate leaves within that period, the fee is either refunded or a replacement candidate is sourced, per the agreed terms.

items.question: Can multiple recruiters submit the same candidate?
items.answer: The platform tracks first-submission attribution. If two recruiters submit the same candidate, the first submission holds. This protects the recruiting community and ensures clear credit.

items.question: What if I'm both the job-poster and the placing recruiter?
items.answer: That's a standard scenario. Recruiting agencies can post roles and work them internally while also opening them to the broader network for split engagement. You control who sees the role and on what terms.

blocks.subtitle: Recruiting has a trust problem. Fees negotiated behind closed doors. Candidates submitted without attribution. Terms that shift after a placement closes. Splits Network was built to end that.
blocks.imageAlt: Clean dashboard interface displaying fee breakdown and placement timeline with full detail

blocks.heading: Why Recruiting Lacks Trust
paragraphs: Traditional recruiting operates on verbal agreements, relationship capital, and institutional memory. When disputes arise — over fee amounts, candidate ownership, or guarantee terms — there's often no authoritative record. The result is friction, missed payments, and damaged relationships.

For independent recruiters, the stakes are higher. They're working on contingency, and if the terms aren't in writing and verified by a system, they're vulnerable. Hiring companies face the same problem in reverse: they have no visibility into how their roles are being worked, who's been submitted, or where a candidate stands at any given moment.

Splits Network was designed around a single principle: every agreement, every action, and every payment must be recorded, visible, and verifiable. Transparency isn't a feature — it's the architecture.

items.title: Fee Structures Published Upfront
items.description: Before any recruiter engages with a role, they see the total placement fee and their split percentage. There is no negotiation after the fact. The terms you agreed to are the terms that govern the placement.

items.title: Automated Fee Calculation

items.title: Dispute Resolution on Record
items.description: If a dispute arises, both parties have access to the same platform record. Our resolution process starts from verifiable facts, not competing recollections.

items.title: Earnings and Payout History
items.description: Every recruiter has a complete record of their earnings, pending payouts, and historical placements. Every company has a corresponding billing history.

blocks.heading: What We Commit to Every User
paragraphs: These are not aspirations. They are design requirements that every feature on the platform must satisfy.

Terms are immutable once agreed. No party can modify the fee or split percentage after both parties have engaged. Changes require a new agreement. Submissions are first-come, permanent. Candidate attribution is set at submission time and does not change. Payments are calculated, not negotiated. When a placement closes, the fee is derived from recorded compensation data — not from a manual invoice that either party creates. Disputes start from the record. Our resolution process treats the platform log as the authoritative account. We do not adjudicate based on claims unsupported by platform data.

blocks.quote: Transparency in recruiting isn't idealism. It's what allows both parties to trust the process enough to engage in the first place.

items.question: Can a company change the fee after I've submitted a candidate?
items.answer: No. Once you engage with a role and accept the posted fee terms, those terms are locked. Any change to the fee structure creates a new role version, and your engagement under the original terms remains valid for any candidates already submitted.

items.question: What if a candidate I submitted is hired months later?
items.answer: Your submission record is permanent. If a candidate you submitted is hired — even after a long process — your attribution is intact and your fee applies.

items.question: Do hiring companies see my candidate's contact details?
items.answer: Candidate contact details are controlled by the submitting recruiter. You choose what profile information is visible to the hiring company before making an introduction. Full contact details are shared only when you explicitly authorize it.

items.question: What happens if a company disputes a fee after placement?
items.answer: Our dispute resolution process begins with the platform record. If the submission timestamp, engagement agreement, and placement confirmation are all on record, the outcome is clear. We do not entertain disputes that attempt to relitigate terms that were agreed on the platform.

title: AI Matching | Splits Network Platform
description: AI-powered candidate-to-role matching built into Splits Network. Score candidates across 40+ dimensions and surface the strongest fits in minutes, not hours.
author: Splits Network

blocks.subtitle: Splits Network's AI matching engine scores every candidate against every open role across 40+ dimensions — skills, experience depth, industry context, and compensation alignment. Recruiters see the strongest matches first.
blocks.imageAlt: AI matching interface showing candidate fit scores against role requirements

blocks.heading: Manual Matching Doesn't Scale
paragraphs: A recruiter with 200 candidates and 15 open roles faces a combinatorial problem that no spreadsheet can solve. Manual matching relies on memory and pattern recognition — both of which degrade under volume.

The cost is real. Qualified candidates get overlooked. Strong roles stay open too long. Submissions that don't fit waste everyone's time. Matching accuracy directly determines placement rate — and placement rate is the business.

blocks.heading: How the Matching Works
paragraphs: The matching engine runs the moment a candidate profile is updated or a new role is posted. It evaluates fit across structured signals — not just keyword overlap.

items.title: Skills Depth Analysis
items.body: Distinguishes between surface-level exposure and demonstrated proficiency. A candidate who used a technology in one project is scored differently from someone with five years of production experience.

items.title: Industry Context Mapping
items.body: Understands that experience in regulated industries — healthcare, finance, government — carries context that transfers selectively. Role requirements and candidate history are mapped accordingly.

items.title: Compensation Alignment
items.body: Cross-references candidate compensation expectations against role budget. Surfaces only candidates whose expectations fall within the role's range, eliminating late-stage surprises.

blocks.imageAlt: Candidate match score breakdown showing skills, experience, and alignment dimensions

blocks.heading: From Hours of Review to Minutes of Action
paragraphs: The difference isn't just speed. It's what the recruiter does with the time saved — more candidate conversations, more client engagement, more placements.

items.title: Before: Manual Triage
items.body: 2–4 hours reviewing candidate profiles per role. Decisions based on gut and proximity bias. Submissions often misaligned with what the hiring manager actually needs.

items.title: After: AI-Assisted Shortlisting
items.body: Top candidates surfaced in minutes. Each with a scored breakdown the recruiter can review, override, or act on immediately. Submissions that land interviews, not just inboxes.

items.title: Always Recruiter-Controlled
items.body: AI recommends. Recruiters decide. Every match score can be reviewed, every dimension inspected. The engine augments judgment — it doesn't replace it.

blocks.imageAlt: Side-by-side comparison of manual screening workflow versus AI-assisted shortlisting

blocks.quote: The match scores changed how I work completely. I used to spend Monday mornings triaging. Now I spend them on calls. My submission-to-interview rate went from 34% to 61% in two months.

items.title: Reverse Match
items.description: Given a role, find the best candidates in your database. Given a candidate, find the roles where they're most competitive.

items.title: Match Alerts
items.description: Get notified when a new candidate enters your database whose profile scores highly against an open role. Act before competing recruiters do.

items.title: Transparent Scoring
items.description: Every match score includes a dimension-by-dimension breakdown. Understand exactly why a candidate ranked where they did.

items.title: Continuous Reranking
items.description: As candidate profiles are updated and role requirements change, match scores update automatically. Your shortlist stays current.

items.title: Feedback Learning
items.description: When you mark a submission as strong or weak, the engine incorporates that signal. Matching improves the more you use it.

items.title: Cross-Network Matching
items.description: Pro subscribers can opt in to anonymous cross-network matching — discovering candidates represented by other recruiters available for split placement.

items.question: Does AI matching require additional setup?
items.answer: No. Matching runs automatically on all candidate profiles and role listings. The more complete a candidate profile and role description, the more accurate the scores — but there is no separate configuration step.

items.question: Can I override or adjust match scores?
items.answer: Yes. Match scores are recommendations, not mandates. You can view the dimension breakdown, adjust weighting for your specific needs, and always choose to submit any candidate you believe is the right fit.

items.question: Is matching available on all plans?
items.answer: Basic match scoring is available on all plans. Advanced features — feedback learning, cross-network matching, and custom dimension weighting — are available on Pro and Enterprise plans.

items.question: How does the engine handle non-traditional career paths?
items.answer: The engine evaluates demonstrated skills and outcomes, not just job titles and tenure. Candidates with unconventional paths who demonstrate the required competencies score accordingly. The goal is finding the right fit, not the right resume format.

title: Billing & Payments | Splits Network Platform
description: Automated fee calculation, invoicing, and payment processing for split-fee placements. Stripe-powered payouts, guarantee period tracking, and transparent fee splits — all handled automatically.
author: Splits Network

blocks.subtitle: From placement confirmation to payout, the billing system handles every calculation, every invoice, and every transfer. Split percentages, guarantee periods, and fee structures are locked in at the start — not disputed at the end.
blocks.imageAlt: Billing dashboard showing placement fees, pending payouts, and completed transactions

blocks.heading: Placement Fees Shouldn't Be Negotiated Twice
paragraphs: In traditional split-fee arrangements, the placement happens and then the billing conversation starts. Who calculates the fee? What percentage applies? When does the guarantee period end? These questions cost time, damage relationships, and occasionally end in disputes that neither party wanted.

Splits Network eliminates ambiguity entirely. Fee structures are agreed upon when a recruiter engages a role, not after a candidate is hired. When a placement is confirmed, the system calculates the fee, issues the invoice, processes the payment, and records everything — automatically.

blocks.heading: From Offer Acceptance to Paid Out
paragraphs: The billing lifecycle follows the placement lifecycle. Every step is tracked. Every number is visible to the relevant parties. Nothing requires a follow-up email.

items.title: Agreed at Engagement
items.body: The hiring company posts the role with fee terms — total percentage and split ratio. Recruiters agree to these terms before submitting candidates. The numbers are fixed.

items.title: Triggered at Confirmation
items.body: When the hiring company confirms a placement, the system immediately calculates the total fee, applies the agreed split, and generates invoices for both parties.

items.title: Tracked Through Guarantee
items.body: The guarantee period countdown begins at start date. If the candidate leaves before the guarantee expires, the system manages the refund or replacement process per the agreed terms.

blocks.imageAlt: Billing timeline showing fee calculation, invoice generation, and payout confirmation

items.title: Configurable Fee Structures
items.description: Set placement fees as a percentage of first-year salary. Define custom split ratios per role — 50/50, 60/40, 70/30, or any configuration that works for your arrangement.

items.title: Automated Invoicing
items.description: Invoices generate automatically on placement confirmation. Both the hiring company and the placing recruiter receive itemized breakdowns immediately.

items.title: Guarantee Period Tracking
items.description: Define guarantee periods from 30 to 180 days. The platform tracks start dates, monitors status, and manages refund or replacement obligations automatically.

items.title: Stripe Integration
items.description: All payments are processed through Stripe. ACH transfers, credit card payments, and international payouts are supported with full transaction history.

items.title: Transaction History
items.description: Complete ledger of every placement fee, split payment, refund, and adjustment. Exportable for your accounting team in any format.

items.title: Multi-Party Splits
items.description: When multiple recruiters contribute to a placement — one sourcing, one managing the process — the system can distribute fees across multiple recipients per the agreed terms.

blocks.quote: We used to spend two weeks chasing invoices after every placement. Now the payment is in process before I've even called to congratulate the candidate. It's changed how I think about the business.
blocks.citation: Rebecca Torres, Founder, Torres Executive Search

cards.title: Hiring Companies
cards.description: Know your fee obligation before the hire is made. Receive clean invoices automatically. Manage guarantee periods without spreadsheets.

cards.title: Recruiters

items.question: When does money actually change hands?
items.answer: Payments are initiated when the guarantee period completes with no reported issues. The hiring company is invoiced at placement confirmation. The payout to the placing recruiter processes when the guarantee window closes. Exact timing depends on payment method — ACH typically settles in 2–3 business days.

items.question: What happens if a candidate leaves during the guarantee period?
items.answer: If a candidate leaves within the guarantee period, the hiring company can request a refund or replacement per the terms set on the original role listing. The platform manages the refund workflow and adjusts any pending payout accordingly.

items.question: Can companies pay via invoice rather than card?
items.answer: Yes. Enterprise accounts support ACH bank transfer and invoice-based billing with net-30 terms. Contact sales to configure this for your account.

items.question: Are there platform fees on top of placement fees?
items.answer: Splits Network charges a platform fee on each completed placement. The fee percentage depends on your subscription plan — it's lower on paid plans than the Starter tier. All platform fees are disclosed before you post a role.

blocks.subtitle: Set your fee terms once. Every placement after that is handled automatically.

title: Split Fees | Splits Network Platform
description: How split-fee recruiting works on Splits Network. Transparent fee structures, automated calculations, configurable splits, guarantee period tracking, and Stripe-powered payouts.
author: Splits Network

blocks.subtitle: Split-fee recruiting connects recruiters who have roles with recruiters who have candidates. The placement happens. The fee is divided. Everyone wins. Splits Network is the infrastructure that makes this scalable, transparent, and enforceable.
blocks.imageAlt: Split fee breakdown diagram showing role owner and candidate owner receiving their respective shares

blocks.heading: Split-Fee Recruiting, Explained
paragraphs: In a split-fee arrangement, two recruiters share responsibility for a placement and divide the fee accordingly. The job-owning recruiter holds the client relationship and the open role. The candidate-owning recruiter holds the talent and does the sourcing.

The model has existed for decades in the recruiting industry — informal agreements, handshake deals, and arrangements managed through phone calls and spreadsheets. What's changed is the infrastructure to make it work at scale, with transparency, and without disputes.
That infrastructure is Splits Network.

blocks.heading: Two Recruiters. One Placement. Transparent Terms.
paragraphs: The split structure is defined before any candidate is submitted. Both parties see the same numbers. There is nothing to renegotiate after the fact.

items.title: The Job-Owning Recruiter
items.body: Holds the relationship with the hiring company. Posts the role on the platform with a defined fee percentage and split ratio. Manages the hiring process through to offer.

items.title: The Candidate-Owning Recruiter
items.body: Has a strong candidate in their network. Sees the role on the marketplace, agrees to the posted split terms, and submits their candidate. If the placement happens, they earn their share.

items.title: The Platform
items.body: Tracks the agreed terms, records every stage of the hiring process, calculates the fee on placement confirmation, and distributes payments to both parties automatically through Stripe.

blocks.imageAlt: Workflow diagram showing job-owning and candidate-owning recruiter roles and how the fee divides on placement

items.title: Configurable Split Ratios
items.description: Set any split ratio that reflects your arrangement — 50/50, 60/40, 70/30. Ratios are visible to all parties before engagement begins.

items.title: Terms Locked at Engagement
items.description: The split percentage and fee structure are fixed when a recruiter accepts a role. They cannot be changed after a candidate is submitted. No retroactive renegotiation.

items.title: Guarantee Period Protection
items.description: Guarantee periods of 30 to 90 days protect both parties. If a candidate leaves during the guarantee window, the refund or replacement obligation is clearly defined and managed automatically.

items.title: Automatic Fee Calculation
items.description: Placement fees calculate instantly from confirmed salary and the posted percentage. Both parties receive a breakdown before any payment is initiated.

items.title: Itemized Invoicing
items.description: Every placement generates separate invoices for the hiring company and the placing recruiter. Clear, professional documentation for accounting on both sides.

items.title: Stripe Payouts
items.description: All fee transfers process through Stripe. Bank transfers, international payments, and payout tracking are handled natively with full transaction history.

blocks.quote: The split-fee model gave me access to roles I could never source on my own. Before Splits Network, I had great candidates and no way to connect them to the right jobs. Now I earn fees on placements I couldn't have made independently.

blocks.heading: The Infrastructure Makes Disputes Unlikely
paragraphs: Most split-fee disputes arise because the terms weren't clear, the timeline wasn't recorded, or the expectations weren't aligned. Splits Network addresses each of these at the point of engagement.

When a recruiter accepts a role, the fee structure is confirmed in writing. When a candidate is submitted, the submission is timestamped and logged. When a placement is confirmed, the calculation is automatic and both parties see the same number. There is nothing ambiguous to dispute.

blocks.heading: A Better Deal for Everyone in the Split

cards.title: Job-Owning Recruiters
cards.description: Access a network of recruiters with deep candidate pools you'd never reach independently. More recruiters on your roles means faster fills and broader coverage.
cards.metricLabel: recruiters who can fill your roles

cards.title: Candidate-Owning Recruiters
cards.description: Submit your best candidates to roles you didn't source. Earn 50–70% of the placement fee with terms defined before you engage. No relationship required.

items.question: What is the typical split ratio?
items.answer: Split ratios are set by the job-owning recruiter when they post the role. The most common arrangement is 50/50 or 60/40 in favor of the placing recruiter. Ratios are visible before any recruiter engages, so both parties enter the arrangement with aligned expectations.

items.question: Who sets the total placement fee percentage?
items.answer: The hiring company sets the total placement fee — typically 15–25% of first-year salary — when they post the role. The recruiter managing the role then sets the split ratio. The candidate-owning recruiter sees both figures before submitting.

items.question: What happens if my candidate is submitted to the same role by another recruiter?
items.answer: If a candidate is submitted by two different recruiters, the first valid submission takes precedence. The platform timestamps every submission and flags potential conflicts. This is visible to the hiring company, who makes the final determination on which submission is active.

items.question: Can I use Splits Network for direct placements, not just splits?
items.answer: Yes. The platform supports direct placements where one recruiter owns both the role and the candidate. In this case, there is no split — the full fee goes to the placing recruiter, minus the platform fee.

items.question: How does the platform handle international splits?
items.answer: Splits Network supports international payments through Stripe. Currency conversion and international transfer fees apply. All amounts are displayed in USD on the platform; local currency conversion is handled by Stripe at the time of transfer.
